awd_titl_txt: Nanoscale Energy and Interfacial Transport Research Based Mentoring Program to increase Underrepresented Minority Students in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal explores how to motivate students from the Saint Louis area, and in particular underrepresented minorities, to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields. A series of integrated education activities are being established based on research conducted in the Nanoscale Energy and Interfacial Transport (NEIT) laboratory. This outreach will enrich the STEM learning experience for the next generation of students, invoke their engineering interest, and quantitatively assess the factors that impede and motivate students to pursue STEM majors. 

The project supports the integration of undergraduate design projects, student talent pipeline programs, and partnerships with high-tech industrial companies. To support broadening participation, the science identity summer workshops provide education and evaluation of the potential social psychological recognition of the value of engineering among minority students. The study seeks to understand how underrepresented minorities can perceive the value of being identified as an engineer as an achievable aspiration. Moreover, this research explores factors that influence underrepresented students? perceptions about science and engineering at a critical developmental stage in which they may deem the workload or value associated with becoming an engineering as not worthwhile in comparison to non-STEM fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Encouraging young students towards careers in STEM is a critical concern in the US for growing a strong economy. Despite the increasing enrollment of STEM students in recent years, the dropout rate in STEM fields remains one of the highest among all subjects, which has led to a pressing demand for qualified professionals in the STEM workforce. As shown in the report by the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology (PCAST), the 6-year B.S. degree completion rate in STEM is less than 40%, while approximately 1 million more STEM professionals will be needed over the next decade. Many STEM courses, such as mathematics, were developed in a cumulative manner so that the subjects can build from very simple principles to very complex advanced topics. However, the classroom teaching for these subjects was often completely “instructor-oriented” and “concept-based”, demotivating half of the college students from continuing on STEM careers who think these subjects are either “too hard” or “not useful”. Such a scenario is particularly severe for underrepresented minorities (URM): only ~20% Black/African-American, Latino, and Native American students completed their STEM degree, and only 17.1% of the workforce in engineering fields are URM who constitute 32.7% of the total U.S. population. The goal of this research was to motivate more local US students, and in particular local underrepresented minorities (URM), to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields. In particular, the PI sek to establish a series of integrated education plans based on his research activities to enrich the STEM learning experience for the young generation, invoke their scientific interest, and to quantitatively assess the impact of these programs on students’ will in pursuing STEM careers.

Throughout the project duration, we organized a series of workshops dedicated to exploring the wettability characteristics of nanoengineered surfaces and highlighting their advantages in thermal transport. Our main focus was to inspire high school students, particularly those from underrepresented minority groups (URM), in the Greater Saint Louis area to pursue STEM-focused careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Numerous high school students from the Greater St. Louis area participated in these workshops, and through interest in STEM surveys, we gained valuable insights into their STEM interests and their enthusiasm for hands-on crafting experiments. Based on the anonymous evaluation survey, 100% of the workshop participants expressed their willingness to recommend the workshop to other students. Additionally, 92% of the students exhibited increased interest in the sciences compared to the previous rate of 64% before attending the workshop. Moreover, the conducted workshops will significantly support high school teachers in enhancing their curriculum, particularly in the domain of thermal transport phenomena. The modules developed during these workshops provide a unique blend of teaching and research experiences, catering to students from diverse backgrounds. The project also introduced a range of new experiments and lessons that can be seamlessly integrated into STEM education curricula in high schools. To facilitate easy access, the workshop materials and resources will be readily available on the NEITLab website, ensuring teachers can readily utilize them in their classrooms.
